title: Ling Cong
text:
Ling Cong () is a <a href="Chinese%20people">Chinese</a>-born <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> former professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> player who last played for <a href="Hong%20Kong%20First%20Division%20League">Hong Kong First Division</a> club <a href="Tuen%20Mun%20SA">Tuen Mun</a>. He played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>.
Career.
Happy Valley.
In the 2008–09 season, Lin Cong scored 15 goals for <a href="Happy%20Valley%20AA">Happy Valley</a> and was the club's top scorer.
On 5 May 2010, Ling Cong was questioned by the <a href="Independent%20Commission%20Against%20Corruption%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">Independent Commission Against Corruption</a> over match fixing. He missed the club's training but team official said he pulled a muscle. On 7 May, Ling Cong said he was questioned for information but he was not arrested and he had nothing to do with the case. It was a mistake for the media to report that he was arrested and he worried about his future in Hong Kong football.
Sun Hei.
Ling Cong joined <a href="Sun%20Hei%20SC">Sun Hei</a> for the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Hong%20Kong%20First%20Division%20League">2010–11 Hong Kong First Division League</a>.
Tuen Mun SA.
Ling Cong joined <a href="Tuen%20Mun%20SA">Tuen Mun SA</a> for the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Hong%20Kong%20First%20Division%20League">2011–12 Hong Kong First Division League</a> season. On 23 October 2011, Lin Cong scored a hat-trick and helped Tuen Mun beat <a href="Sham%20Shui%20Po%20SA">Sham Shui Po</a> 6:2.
On 30 October 2012, due to the divestment of Tuen Mun president Chan Keung, various key players, including Ling Cong, and the whole coaching team were released by the club.
